prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We can easily afford a spectral averaging factor of 16 to reduce our data rates and still obtain the spectral resolution we need.

Even the most compact C36-1 configuration will already spatially resolve the individual lensed images of our DSFGs. We would also accept the C36-2 configuration. Any larger arrays would risk over-resolving our sources.

To estimate the expected line flux, we used the known L_FIR and [CII] line width of our sources (Gullberg et al. 2015), and scaled these with the relations of Spinoglio et al. 2012. As there may be a significant variation in these fluxes, we aim for a S/N>10.
In order to spectrally resolve the sources, we aim for a resolution of 50 km/s. If the source is spatially resolved into multiple components, we still have the option to integrate over the full line width to increase S/N.
We can easily afford a spectral averaging factor of 16 to reduce our data rates and still obtain the spectral resolution we need.

In order to spectrally resolve the sources, we aim for a resolution of 50 km/s. If the source is spatially resolved into multiple components, we still have the option to integrate over the full line width to increase S/N.

We can easily afford a spectral averaging factor of 16 to reduce our data rates and still obtain the spectral resolution we need. Note that this broad line is expected to cover virtually the entire baseband 2, but we have placed two contiguous continuum bands just below and above this baseband to allow a continuum subtraction.

Even the most compact C36-1 configuration will already spatially resolve the individual lensed images of our DSFGs. We would also accept the C36-2 configuration. Any larger arrays would risk over-resolving our sources.

To estimate the expected line flux, we used the known L_FIR and [CII] line width of our sources (Gullberg et al. 2015), and scaled these with the relations of Spinoglio et al. 2012. As there may be a significant variation in these fluxes, we aim for a S/N>4.
In order to spectrally resolve the sources, we aim for a resolution of 200 km/s (note that this is one of the broadest lines in our sample). If the source is spatially resolved into multiple components, we still have the option to integrate over the full line width to increase S/N.
We can easily afford a spectral averaging factor of 16 to reduce our data rates and still obtain the spectral resolution we need.

Even the most compact C36-1 configuration will already spatially resolve the individual lensed images of our DSFGs. We would also accept the C36-2 configuration. Any larger arrays would risk over-resolving our sources.

To estimate the expected line flux, we used the known L_FIR and [CII] line width of our sources (Gullberg et al. 2015), and scaled these with the relations of Spinoglio et al. 2012. As there may be a significant variation in these ratios, we aim for a S/N>8.
In order to spectrally resolve the sources, we aim for a resolution of 110 km/s. If the source is spatially resolved into multiple components, we still have the option to integrate over the full line width to increase S/N.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The [OI]63?m line is one of the two brightest fine structure lines in galaxies, and the only one probing very dense neutral gas. Therefore, in a dusty ISM, studying [OI]63?m is the only way to uncover components which may not be associated with standard component HII regions or PDRs, such as AGN or unusually dense, compact star-forming regions, which are suspected to be present in IR-luminous galaxies at high redshifts. Despite its brightness and importance, the [OI]63?m line has only been marginally detected in two high-redshift galaxies, because its rest wavelength requires both sensitive high-frequency receivers and samples of very high redshift targets. We here propose to exploit the unique combination of ALMA bands 9 and 10, and the sample of distant strongly lensed dusty star-forming galaxies in the SPT survey. Thanks to our 1.4mm selection wavelength, our sample contains as many as 13 z>4.2 objects where [OI]63?m is now observable with ALMA bands 9 and 10. Combined with the already available FIR and [CII] data on our targets, this will show the important diagnostic power of the [OI]63?m line to constrain the physical properties of the ISM in high-redshift galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
